Notice.Title: DInfoCom/0174 - Provision of Exploitation of Tactical Data Links within Land Information Manoeuvre
Notice.Description:
The Land Environment Tactical Communications and Information Systems (LE TacCIS) programme aims to deliver tactical military communications and consists of multiple projects delivering elements of an intended single network. The LE TacCIS Innovation, Research Experimentation (IRE) activities aims to conduct programme level research and experimentation to de-risk solution development for a wider Land Domain Communication and Information System (LD CIS) perspective and consider what areas require development to ensure that individual projects remain able to deliver their elements of the Single Information Environment.
The intent of the LE TacCIS-IRE activities includes technical de-risking of programme themes and addressing themes that cover multiple projects and provides a means of including innovative thought into LE TacCIS. This activity will support the Networks theme of the IRE activities and in particular Tactical Data Links (TDL).
Tactical Information exchange has never needed to be more accurate, agile and timely to keep pace with persistent and high tempo changes across the battlespace. To achieve an efficient and effective tactical outcome in national and international environments, the automated and secure exchange of (near) real-time Situational Awareness, Battlespace Management and Command and Control functions can be fulfilled by Tactical Data Links. Several varieties of TDLs have been developed, each designed to support a difference domain and/or warfare demand.
Building on the outputs of Phase 1 TDL study conducted in 2021 (DInfoCom/0125), deliver a more detailed technical study on the technicalities and practical implementation of a TDL network architecture within the Land Domain that can complement current and future LE TacCIS and Land ISTAR capabilities (and other multi domain links).

AwardDetail.SupplierAddress: Malvern Hills Science Park Geraldine Road Great Malvern Worcestershire WR14 3SZ

Notice.Title: CEFAS22-91 Services to review the feasibility of setting up a Solid Waste Producers and Recyclers Association in Belize and provide a proposal on its implementation accordingly (Cefas Direct Award)
Notice.Description:
The supplier will review Belize's current solid waste infrastructure, policies and capabilities to assess whether implementing a Solid Waste Producers and Recyclers Association would be appropriate for Belize. The supplier will apply their previous experience and expertise of working on similar successful models that have been applied in other Small Island Developing Nations including Samoa and the Solomon Islands. The supplier is required to make recommendations to the Belize Solid Waste Management Authority on the feasibility of the Association, and if it is deemed feasible, the supplier will provide a proposal on the implementation and structure of such an association in Belize. For example, identification of the key stakeholders, and the legal and organisational structures to be implemented, to maximise the success.
Cefas will facilitate engagement and introductory meetings between the supplier and key stakeholders.
Deliverables:
1. Provide a set of recommendations, in writing and via engagement with Cefas and the Belize Solid Waste Management Authority, to advise on the feasibility of setting up a Solid Waste Producers and Recyclers Association in Belize.
2. (If feasible) Provide an outline proposal in writing to Cefas and the Belize Solid Wast Management Authority as to how this Assocation could be implemented in Belize, to include: a. Recommended Stakeholder Participation (as a minimum): Who needs to be involved in the Association (e.g. legal/government/policy, waste producers, waste recyclers, communities). b. Financial Structures: What financial structures should be put in place to maximise transparency and opportunities for funding (e.g. from multi-lateral funders). c. Management and Governance: What structures should be put in place to ensure transparency and effective management, to maximise the ability of the association to increase the effectiveness of solid waste systems management in Belize. d. Collaborative Waste Management: How can the Association work with the existing solid waste landscape in Belize to maximise opportunities to coordinate stakeholders within the sector and across other sectors (e.g. environmental NGOs, tourism, education).

Notice.Title: Provision of Microsoft Dynamics - Catalyst and Implementation Partner via CCS RM6100 Technology Services 3 (Lot 2: Transition and Transformation)
Notice.Description:
Southend Borough Council (SBC)'s current customer service and self-service platform is now no longer fit for purpose and the contract with the current provider ends in August 2023. SBC wishes to use this opportunity to replace the existing technology with a solution that meets residents' digital empowerment and service needs. Technology is a key enabler to achieving Southend's 2050 outcomes strategy, enables SBC's agreed Future Ways of Working design principles and enables the Council's Executive Team and Cabinet's to undertake their responsibilities.
SBC has selected the Microsoft Catalyst programme design route, followed by use of the Microsoft Dynamics platform in order to capitalise on the funding and consultancy support available from Microsoft.
The desired outcome of the Catalyst (design) phase of work will be a robust, definitive business case; that includes a solution architecture and financial case with which SBC can use to gain the appropriate internal financial approval and obtain funding. The partner will also make recommendations on any additional licensing requirements, which will be purchased by SBC. The purchase of any additional licenses falls outside the scope of this contract.
Following on from the approval of the business case, the partner will assist SBC in delivering our collaborative new state design as per the Catalyst programme output, by implementing the new platform and assisting to realise the benefits that were identified in the business case. The partner will additionally help to encourage the organisational change required for the new processes and culture to be embedded by delivering knowledge transfer to SBC Officers, through the use of appropriate resources and training materials, so that SBC can develop the in-house capability to update and change processes and systems, and onboard new services as and when required.

Notice.Title: CEFAS22-90 Services to advise the Department of the Environment (DOE) of Belize on a small rural solid waste collection pilot scheme (Cefas Direct Award)
Notice.Description:
The supplier will advise the Department of the Environment (DOE) of Belize on how they can optimise the design, implementation, accounting, management and evaluation of a new rural waste collection pilot scheme in central-western Belize. The supplier will apply their previous experience and expertise of working on similar projects of this kind in other Small Island Developing States and/or developing nation rural communities.
The supplier will be required to review documentation provided by DOE, review any available data and hold discussions with the DOE as required. Cefas will facilitate engagement and introductory meetings between the supplier and key stakeholders, including DOE.
Deliverables:
1. Provide recommendations to DOE and, where possible, provide documentation to DOE that will support them to deliver a successful waste collection pilot scheme via the following non-exhaustive listed areas;
a. Collection design: Make recommendations to DOE on collection design, taking into account the available resources, transport and the culture in Belize; provide best available practices (from similar/previous successes). b. Implementation: Make recommendations to DOE on strategies for implementation to maximise success, e.g. sensitising stakeholders, publishing collection time tables etc. c. Accounting: Make recommendations to DOE to help ensure that the proposed waste collection system can be sustainably funded in the long-term, and to ensure transparency of funding and accounting to engender trust. d. Management: Make recommendations to DOE on methods that can be utilised to manage the solid waste pilot in a way that will maximise the chances for long-term success and sustainability. e. Evaluation and Recommendations: Advise DOE on methods that could be used to evaluate the success of the pilot, and to make recommendations on improvements and how to scale the pilot across the whole country.
The Contract was a Direct Award to the Supplier due to creation and ownership of methods and data required for the work.

Notice.Title: WCC Artificial Intelligence Sensor Framework
Notice.Description:
Warwickshire County Council (the Council) is seeking supplier who can provide artificial intelligence (AI) data monitoring devices to record, collect and analyse data accurately for developing schemes and strategies for all modes of transport and updating traffic modelling tools. These developments and schemes can include but are not limited to new housing developments, new or improved cycling and walking facilities and improvements to road layouts. Hosting for all and relocation for some of the devices are also required
Warwickshire County Council will be using its e-tendering system (In-Tend) for the administration of this procurement process and providers must register with the system to be able to express an interest.
The web address is: www.csw-jets.co.uk
Registration and use of In-Tend is free. Once registered, all correspondence for this procurement process must be via the in-tend correspondence function. However, if you are unable to register with the website please email us at procurement@warwickshire.gov.uk
During the course of the contract period the range and scope of these services may be subject to modification and variation to meet the changing needs and requirements of the Council, potential changes in legislation and the changing demands placed on the Council by its customers.

Notice.Title: BT1116 Emergency Funds for people in crisis
Notice.Description:
The economic impact of COVID-19 has realised an increasing number of families in Luton falling into poverty. Previous analysis has shown that poverty and financial hardship can have an adverse impact on quality of life and opportunities, with many of our most deprived residents facing poorer outcomes relating to health, education and life chances. It is therefore vital that we prioritise services and interventions that prevent our residents from falling into a cycle of deprivation, reduce inequalities and alleviate the impact of poverty.
The council recognises that with the effects of Covid-19, the rise in unemployment, escalated property costs and wage growth struggling to keep pace with inflation in Luton, people living in poverty can often pay more for goods and services as they are unable to make up front costs and then find themselves in greater pressures when managing household budgets for essential costs. In light of this, both local and central governments across the country are bringing forward schemes for local welfare support to assist those most in need and with the relevant tools to intervene early and support those most in need, the council hope to put their residents back on their feet.
Currently Luton Council operates a discretionary and preventative Local Welfare Assistance scheme providing emergency provision for individuals or families suffering from severe hardship which means that they are unable to source and fund food or utility payments. The scheme does not currently make cash payments but referrals to organisations such as the food bank and/or vouchers for utility payments.

Report to include: - A high-level assessment of each of the options provided to the company by their own advisors -A review of updated financial information provided by the company (and their advisors) including the 13 week cash flow forecast to assess the options/levers available to minimise cost and overall funding to a potential sale; - A commentary on the conditions that could be attached to any funding/loan to the company including ways in which the facility can be structured to minimise cash leakage; - Review and comment on a potential option associated with HMG acquiring the site for a deferred consideration and leasing the site back to the company. -To comment on any other feasible options available to the company above and beyond the options considered above. To review and comment on the first draft of the terms sheet being prepared by BEIS

Notice.Title: Oracle Fusion - Phase 2 Business Transformation
Notice.Description:
Following the implementation of Oracle Cloud, the Authority is committed to building a fully integrated Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) solution. To further this commitment, it will need to continually work across programmes of Business Transformation. These programmes would leverage the most value from Oracle Cloud technology with the express aim of improving user experience enhancing business value offset and measured against the financial investment.
The deliverables would include areas such as final implementation of Learning Cloud and Health & Safety Modules and adoption of new modules including Digital Assistant and Guided Learning, Strategic Workforce Planning, Business Process Change, Business Transformation Consultancy and Oracle Enterprise Performance Management. The contract has been awarded through G-Cloud 12.

Notice.Description:
Reducing domestic abuse is a priority for Liverpool City Council (LCC). Tragically, Liverpool suffers high levels of reported domestic violence and abuse that have human and financial costs for individuals, families and the city.
Liverpool City Council (LCC) is recommissioning a range of domestic abuse services as follows: • Three women's Refuges: o Refuge provision for minority ethnic groups o Refuge provision in the north and south of the city
• Supported accommodation for teenage parents

Notice.Title: Subcontracting Framework (Adult Education Budget)
Notice.Description:
Eastleigh College is seeking to establish a framework of up to four suitable training providers to deliver Adult Education Budget funded training in line with our College strategy and the ESFA's published guidance. Awards under the framework will range from £100,000 to £600,000.
The procurement is following the light-touch regime outlined in regulations 74 to 77 of the Public Contract Regulations 2015.
This will be a three-year framework, with a focus predominantly on localised delivery within South Hampshire and the Solent region.
The timeline for the procurement is as follows:
• 30th June 2022: Launch • 15th July 2022: Closing date for PQQ returns and due diligence • 18th - 22nd July 2022: Shortlisting and scoring (including financial health) • 25th - 29th July 2022: Interview panel (including quality assessment) • 1st August 2022: Procurement conclusion and awards • 2nd-12th August 2022: Standstill period • 15th August 2022 Contracts issued for signing
Those able to meet the following requirements as a minimum will score more favourably than those who cannot:
• Delivery local to South Hampshire and the Solent region • Delivery of the following specialisms from our 2020-2024 Strategy o Construction and building services o Health, science, care and public services o Business, customer service, administration, human resources, finance and law o Education, training and careers o Digital skills • Providers with a current full inspection (within the past 3 years) outcome of 'outstanding' or 'good'. • Monitoring visits judgements of 'reasonable' and 'significant' progress.
Submission template documents are available via the Eastleigh College website: https://www.eastleigh.ac.uk/about/policies-and-procedures/subcontractor-framework-procurement/
All communications and submissions should be sent to compliance@eastleigh.ac.uk.

Notice.Title: Evaluation partner: engagement with children and young people - National Keyworking Evaluation
Notice.Description:
NHS Arden and GEM Commissioning Support Unit (AGEM) has been commissioned to conduct an evaluation of the Keyworking Programme. The evaluation will focus on early adopter areas and use mixed methods to test the theory of change described in a single logic model.
The aim of this exercise is to contract with a suitably experienced and qualified supplier to ensure appropriate engagement, using qualitative evaluations methods, with autistic Children and Young people (CYP) and CYP with learning disabilities and parents/ carers. The successful bidder will be responsible for designing and completing robust and adaptive data collection, in line with the Evaluation Framework, from CYP allocated a Keyworker, and parents/ carers in participating sites. The successful bidder will also be responsible for analysing and reporting findings to inform the wider national evaluation led by NHS Arden & GEM CSU.

Notice.Description:

They will challenge contractors processes and programme to achieve time and cost savings. A key capability will be the ability to drive a right first-time approach in all construction areas but in particular in the design, installation, commissioning and handover of tunnel systems.
National Highways has sought a partner with the capability and skills that extend beyond that of providing design and construction quality assurance support and project management.

Notice.Title: Exploration of affordable housing for the SNEE nursing workforce
Notice.Description:
This is a Contract Award Notice to communicate a contract award by NHS Suffolk and North East Essex Integrated Care Board (the "ICB").
The contract award is made to Iceni Projects Limited for the provision of a data collection exercise, needs assessment, completion of a prospective report, and completion of an impact considerations document pertaining to affordable housing for the Suffolk and North East Essex nursing workforce.
The overarching ambition is to support NHS staff, and in this instance, the nursing workforce, to be able to access housing that meets their needs in terms of affordability, demographics, and location to their place of work.
This contract commences on 14th November 2022 until 13th February 2023, at a total contract value of £29,700 (inclusive of VAT).
The ICB is publishing this Contract Award Notice in the Contracts Finder in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (as amended by The Public Procurement (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020) for spend above £25,000.

Notice.Title: CEFAS22-89 Services for development of a Terms of Reference for a port upgrade pilot project proposal in Belize (Cefas Direct Award)
Notice.Description:
The supplier will develop a Terms of Reference (ToR) document, in order for Cefas to then run an open competition for a supplier to propose a pilot project for the upgrade of a candidate port (or ports) in Belize to meet MARPOL (The International Convention for Prevention of Marine Pollution For Ships) requirements. The ToR is required to instruct the subsequently appointed supplier on the review and update of recommendations made by the Asia Pacific Waste Consulting (APWC) on Belize's Port Reception Waste Facilities, completed in 2019 during the Commonwealth Litter Programme (CLiP). The candidate port (or ports) will be decided by the Belize Ports Authority, as the organisation in Belize with the legal mandate for Belize's ports. The proposed pilot project will also include proposals to upgrade corresponding waste management infrastructure, to sustainably manage the influx of waste that will develop from the upgraded facilities. It shall also sight the pilot project proposal within Belize's policies and strategies for the marine environment. For the ToR review, Cefas will facilitate engagement and introductory meetings between the supplier and key stakeholders, such as the Belize Ports Authority, Department of the Environment (DOE) and the Ministry for Blue Economy and Civil Aviation. Deliverables: 1. Engage with key stakeholders, as facilitated by Cefas, to discuss the requirements. 2. Develop a ToR document to instruct a subsequent supplier (to be appointed via open competition) on the requirement to develop a pilot project proposal for the upgrade of a candidate port (or ports) in Belize to meet MARPOL requirements. a. The ToR will be appropriately seated in the existing and on-going maritime policy landscape in Belize, for example the Belize National Marine Litter Action Plan. 3. Provide an interim, draft version of the ToR for Cefas to review and provide comment on for Cefas and Belize Ports Authority. 4. Provide a final, clean version of the new ToR document for Cefas to review and approve. 5. Provide an explanatory document alongside the final ToR, documenting the decisions and reasoning of the contents of the ToR. 6. Provide a high-level estimation of the value for an appropriate organisation (to be appointed via open competition) to deliver the work that has been set out in the ToR.
The Contract was a Direct Award to the Supplier due to creation and ownership of methods and data required for the work.
Notice.CpvDescription: Research and development services and related consultancy services and Environmental management

Notice.Title: CEFAS22-88 Contract for review of Belize Ports Authority Terms of Reference (ToR) document regarding maritime activities in Belize (Cefas Direct Award)
Notice.Description:
The Supplier will review a Terms of Reference (ToR) document provided by the Belize Ports Authority, in order for Cefas to run an open competition for a supplier to review Belize's current and emerging maritime activities and relevant policies. The supplier appointed via the subsequent open competition will make recommendations for policy improvements to meet stated objectives of the Belize Ports Authority and that support sustainable development and integration of the maritime sector with other activities and policies in the marine environment. For the ToR review, Cefas will facilitate engagement and introductory meetings between the supplier and key stakeholders, including the Belize Ports Authority, Department of the Environment (DOE) and the Ministry for Blue Economy and Civil Aviation. Deliverables: 1. Engage with key stakeholders, as facilitated by Cefas, to discuss the requirement. 2. Review ToR provided by the Belize Ports Authority and make recommendations that will ensure the ToR reflect their stated objectives. a. Note: any policy recommendations or reviews that the ToR state require that the supplier appropriately seats those recommendations within the existing and developing maritime policy landscape in Belize. 3. Provide an interim, tracked-changes version of the ToR for Cefas to review and provide comment on. 4. Provide a final, clean version of the new ToR document for Cefas to review and approve. 5. Provide an explanatory document alongside the final ToR, documenting the changes and why they have been made. 6. Provide a high-level estimation of the value for an appropriate organisation (to be appointed via open competition) to deliver the work that has been set out in the ToR.
The Contract was a Direct Award to the Supplier due to creation and ownership of methods and data required for the work.

Notice.Title: CEFAS22-129 Contract for Marine Underwater Imagery Analysis for Fulmar MCZ
Notice.Description:
Cefas wishes to commission a contract to undertake the analysis of seabed imagery (still images and video) collected from Fulmar MCZ in 2021.
- Analysis will be undertaken as set out in imagery specification provided for this work ('Imagery Spec', included as part of the tender package) and adhering to the NMBAQC Epibiota interpretation guidelines (Turner et al, 2016).
- The online annotation software BIIGLE will be used to annotate video and still images as described in the analysis specification.
- Video tows are to be segmented into areas of continuous broadscale seabed habitat type greater than or equal to 5m along transect distance. Sea-pen and burrowing megafauna analysis transects will be additionally analysed using frames taken from the video.
- A minimum of 10% of the videos and stills should be re-analysed for QA purposes by the contractor and reported on.
- An external QA (10% reanalysis) will be undertaken in advance of final data delivery. Following award of the contract, and dependent on the evaluation scores they achieved, unsuccessful bidders may be invited to undertake the independent external QA aspects of this project. Please indicate in your tender if you wish to be considered for this work.
- Any deviation from this methodology should be approved in writing by the Cefas project officer.
- The successful tenderer will produce an analysis report.
- Substrate and taxonomic image reference collections are required
- A start-up meeting will be held with the winning tenderer within a week of the contract being awarded. During the start-up meeting Cefas will provide guidance on use of BIIGLE in MPA projects if needed.

Notice.Title: Evaluation partner for CYP Diabetes transition pilots
Notice.Description: The appointment of Ipsos MORI to work as an evaluation partner to work with up to 21 pilot sites between September 2022-March 2025 to identify key scalable themes and learning to underpin improvements in diabetes transition and young adult care. They will co-develop a common minimum data set across all sites, linked to nationally available audit metrics; support continuous learning between, and across test sites assessing what worked well in terms of design and delivery, what could be improved. As well as assessing the impact of the pilot programme on key diabetes outcomes and health care costs. The evaluation will help ensure the development of sustainable service models to maximise improvements in outcomes for Children and young adults transitioning from paediatric care.

Notice.Title: Digital Engagement Platform
Notice.Description: Sheffield City Council is looking to appoint a provider of a software solution that allows us to actively consult with Sheffield's citizens. As a Local Authority we have a statutory duty to consult with members of the public on certain decisions, and whilst that engagement and consultation cannot rely solely on digital methods, a high-quality, accessible, and user-friendly digital engagement platform which facilitates our wider ambitions to be a listening and responsive organisation is required. This is where you as a supplier come in with your solution to support our ambition to be an organisation that works with local communities to better the city. The public want more options for online engagement, which is more flexible, succinct, and usable for their lives and priorities in 2022 and for the future; and the public now expect a wider range of engagement approaches rather than solely online surveys (although this function is still essential.) As the fourth largest city in the UK, we should be setting the standard for community engagement, and this underpins our ambition. Your proposed solution should also factor in it being a corporate solution for the whole Council, and having one platform that suits the needs of the whole organisation is the best use of resource but also allows for oversight of all the digital engagement we're undertaking as an organisation meaning we're less likely to ask the same people the same questions and we make our data and insight work smarter than it is. The procured platform will also be used for staff engagement, with an aim to increase the numbers of staff who engage.

NWP own the Cisco equipment and require the supplier to proactively manage both the equipment and day to day operational service delivery (respond to incidents, requests and changes) liaising with the provider where required.
The contract will be for a initial period of 4 years with the possibility of extending it for an additional 3 years. The start date will be agreed with the current provider and the new to allow sufficient time for handover to be competed.
